sen.j: 禁門の変（きんもんのへん）は、江戸時代後期の元治元年7月19日 (旧暦)（1864年8月20日）に起きた事件である。
sen.e: The Hamaguri Rebellion (kinmon no hen) occurred on August 20th, 1864 (the first year of the Genji era, July 19th in the old calendar) in the final days of the Edo period.
The Hamaguri Rebellion (kinmon no hen) occurred on August 20th, 1864 (the first year of the Genji era, July 19th in the old calendar) in the final days of the Edo period.
The Hamaguri Rebellion (kinmon no hen) occurred on August 20, 1864 (the first year of the Genji era, July 19th in the old calendar) in the final days of the Edo period.

sen.j: 蛤御門の変（はまぐりごもんのへん）、元治の変（げんじのへん）、元治甲子の変とも呼ばれる。
sen.e: It is also known as the Incident at the Forbidden Gate, the Incident at the Hamaguri (Frog) Gate, the Genji Incident, and the Incident in the First Year of Genji.
sen.cmt: "Incident" seems better than "Rebellion" but still not ideal.
sen.e: It is also known as the Incident at the Forbidden Gate, the Incident at the Hamaguri (Frog) Gate, the Genji Incident, and the Incident in the First Year of Genji.
It is also known as the Incident at the Forbidden Gate, the Incident at the Hamaguri (Clam) Gate, the Genji Incident, and the Incident in the First Year of Genji.

sen.j: 「禁門」とは「禁裏の御門」の略した呼び方である。
sen.e: "Forbidden Gate" is an abbreviation of "the gate of the forbidden palace" (meaning the Emperor's palace).
"Forbidden Gate" is an abbreviation of "the gate of the forbidden palace" (meaning the Emperor's palace).
"Forbidden Gate" is an abbreviation of "the gate of the forbidden palace" (meaning the Emperor's palace).

sen.j: 蛤御門の名前の由来は、天明の大火（1788年1月30日 (旧暦)）の際、それまで閉じられていた門が初めて開門されたので、焼けて口を開ける蛤に例えられた為である。
sen.e: The reason it came to be called Hamaguri (Frog) Gate was that during the great Tenmei fire (on January 30th, 1788 in the old calendar), the gate, which had until then always remained closed, was opened for the first time, and thus resembled a frog opening its mouth after being burned.

The reason it came to be called Hamaguri (Frog) Gate was that during the great Tenmei fire (on January 30th, 1788 in the old calendar), the gate, which had until then always remained closed, was opened for the first time, and thus resembled a frog opening its mouth after being burned.

The reason it came to be called Hamaguri (Clam) Gate was that during the great Tenmei fire (on January 30, 1788 in the old calendar), the gate, which had until then always remained closed, was opened for the first time, and thus resembled a clam's shell opening in response to being subjected to fire.

sen.j: 蛤御門は現在の京都御苑の西側に位置し、天明の大火以前は新在家御門と呼ばれていた。
sen.e: The Hamaguri Gate is located in the west side of the modern-day Imperial gardens in Kyoto; before the Great Tenmei fire, it was known as the Shinzaike Gate.
The Hamaguri Gate is located on the west side of the modern-day Imperial gardens in Kyoto; before the Great Tenmei fire, it was known as the Shinzaike Gate
The Hamaguri Gate is located on the west side of the modern-day Imperial gardens in Kyoto; before the Great Tenmei fire, it was known as the Shinzaike Gate

sen.j: 禁門の変が蛤御門の変とも呼ばれるのは、蛤御門付近が激戦区であった為である。
sen.e: The Incident at the Forbidden Gate also came to be called the Hamaguri Rebellion because the fiercest fighting occurred close by the Hamaguri Gate.
The Incident at the Forbidden Gate also came to be called the Hamaguri Rebellion because the fiercest fighting occurred near the Hamaguri Gate.
The Incident at the Forbidden Gate also came to be called the Hamaguri Rebellion because the fiercest fighting occurred near the Hamaguri Gate.

sen.j: その為今も門の梁には弾痕が残る。
sen.e: Hence, even today bullet holes remain in the beams of the gate.
Even today, bullet holes remain in the beams of the gate.
Even today, bullet holes remain in the beams of the gate.

tit.cmt: Summaryに修正 他ファイルと統一

sen.j: 尊皇攘夷論を掲げて京都での政局に関わっていた長州藩は、1863年（文久3年）に会津藩と薩摩藩が協力した八月十八日の政変で京都を追放されていた。
sen.e: Choshu han (domain) had raised the sonno joi (Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarians) slogan and begun interfering in the political situation in Kyoto; in 1863 (the third year of the Bunkyu era), the Aizu and Satsuma domains joined forces and on August 18th launched a coup to expel Choshu from Kyoto.

Choshu han (domain) had raised the sonno joi (Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarians) slogan and begun interfering in the political situation in Kyoto; in 1863 (the third year of the Bunkyu era), the Aizu and Satsuma domains joined forces and on August 18th launched a coup to expel Choshu from Kyoto.

Choshu han (clan) had raised the sonno joi (Revere the Emperor, Expel the Barbarians) slogan and begun interfering in the political situation in Kyoto; in 1863, the Aizu and Satsuma clans joined forces and on August 18 launched a coup to expel Choshu from Kyoto.
sen.cmt: domain→clan (the third year of the Bunkyu era)年号が特別な意味をもたないので、削除日付表記

sen.j: 藩主の毛利敬親と子の毛利定広は国許へ謹慎を命じられて政治主導権を失っており、京や大坂に密かに潜伏した数名の長州尊攘派はにわかに行動を続けていた。
sen.e: The daimyo of Choshu, Tadachika MORI, and his son Sadahiro were ordered into house arrest in their hometown and lost the authority to lead politically, but in the capital and in Osaka, several Imperial loyalists from Choshu continued to work secretly to restore the Emperor to power.

The daimyo of Choshu, Tadachika MORI, and his son Sadahiro were ordered into house arrest in their hometown and lost their authority to lead politically, but in the capital and in Osaka, several Imperial loyalists from Choshu continued to work secretly to restore the Emperor to power.

The daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) of Choshu, Tadachika MORI, and his son Sadahiro MORI were ordered into house arrest in their hometown and lost their authority to lead politically, but in the capital and in Osaka, several Imperial loyalists from Choshu continued to work secretly to restore the Emperor to power.

sen.j: 元治元年に入ると、孝明天皇を再び長州陣営のものとする為、京都に乗り込もうとする積極策が長州で論じられた（この時の積極的に上洛を説いたのが、来島又兵衛、久坂玄瑞。
sen.e: Arriving in 1864 (the first year of Genji), those in Choshu debated whether to adopt a proactive plan of marching on Kyoto in a second attempt to win Emperor Komei over to the Choshu camp (at this point, the two arguing for the active advance on Kyoto were Matabe KIJIMA and Genzui KUSAKA.)

Arriving in 1864 (the first year of Genji), those in Choshu debated whether to adopt a proactive plan to march on Kyoto in a second attempt to win Emperor Komei over to the Choshu camp (at this point, the two arguing for the active advance on Kyoto were Matabe KIJIMA and Genzui KUSAKA.)

Arriving in 1864, those in Choshu debated whether to adopt a proactive plan to march on Kyoto in a second attempt to win Emperor Komei over to the Choshu camp (at this point, the two arguing for the active advance on Kyoto were Matabe KIJIMA and Genzui KUSAKA.)
sen.cmt: (the first year of Genji)年号が特別な意味をもたないので、削除

sen.j: 反対、慎重派が桂小五郎と高杉晋作）。
sen.e: Those who opposed the plan included Kogoro KATSURA and Shinsaku TAKASUGI of the prudence faction).
Those who opposed the plan included Kogoro KATSURA and Shinsaku TAKASUGI of the prudence faction).
Those who opposed the plan included Kogoro KATSURA and Shinsaku TAKASUGI of the prudence faction).

sen.j: 6月5日 (旧暦)の池田屋事件で新選組に藩士を殺された変報が長州にもたらされると、慎重派の周布政之助、高杉晋作や宍戸左馬之助らは藩論の沈静化に努めるが、福原越後や益田右衛門介、国司信濃の三家老等の積極派は、討薩賊会奸を掲げて挙兵し、益田、久坂玄瑞らは大山崎町天王山、宝山に、国司、来島又兵衛らは嵯峨天龍寺に、福原越後は伏見長州屋敷に兵を集めて陣営を構える。
sen.e: When word of the Ikedaya Incident of the eighth of July (June 5th in the old calendar), in which Shinsengumi forces had assassinated domainal warriors, reached Choshu, the prudence faction, which included Masanosuke SUFU, Shinsaku TAKASUGI, and Samanosuke SHISHIDO, tried to calm the raging debate in the domain, but the members of the activist faction like the elders of the three clans, Echigo (Mototake) FUKUHARA, Uemonnosuke (Kanenobu) MASUDA, and Shinano (Chikasuke) KUNISHI, cunningly created a group designed to destroy Satsuma, against whom there was considerable emnity, and to that end they prepared for battle; Masuda and Kusaka began gathering troops at Mt. Tenno and Mt. Takara in the town of Oyamazaki, while Kunishi and Kijima gathered troops at Saga Tenryuji temple, and Fukuhara at the Choshu estate at Fushimi.

When word of the July 8th Ikedaya Incident (June 5th in the old calendar), in which the Shinsengumi forces had assassinated domainal samurai warriors, reached Choshu, the prudence faction, which included Masanosuke SUFU, Shinsaku TAKASUGI, and Samanosuke SHISHIDO, tried to calm the raging debate in the domain, but members of the activist faction, like the elders of the three clans, Echigo (Mototake) FUKUHARA, Uemonnosuke (Kanenobu) MASUDA, and Shinano (Chikasuke) KUNISHI, cunningly created a group designed to destroy Satsuma, against whom there was considerable emnity, and to that end they prepared for battle; Masuda and Kusaka began gathering troops at Mt. Tenno and Mt. Takara in the town of Oyamazaki, while Kunishi and Kijima gathered troops at Saga Tenryuji temple, and Fukuhara at the Choshu estate at Fushimi.
sen.cmt: sentence structure rearranged to read "the July 8th Incident Ikedaya Incident (June 5th in the old calendar)," "the" removed from before "members of the activist faction" comma inserted after "faction"
sen.e: When word of the July 8 Ikedaya Incident, in which the Shinsengumi forces had assassinated domainal samurai warriors, reached Choshu, the prudence faction, which included Masanosuke SUFU, Shinsaku TAKASUGI, and Samanosuke SHISHIDO, tried to calm the raging debate in the clan, but members of the activist faction, like the elders of the three clans, Echigo (Mototake) FUKUHARA, Uemonnosuke (Kanenobu) MASUDA, and Shinano (Chikasuke) KUNISHI, cunningly created a group designed to destroy Satsuma, against whom there was considerable enmity, and to that end they prepared for battle; Masuda and Gensui KUSAKA began gathering troops at Mt. Tenno and Mt. Takara in the town of Oyamazaki, while Kunishi and Matabe KIJIMA gathered troops at Saga Tenryu-ji temple, and Echigo FUKUHARA at the Choshu estate at Fushimi.
sen.cmt: 日付表記(June 5th in the old calendar)年号が特別な意味をもたないので、削除domain→clanKusaka→Gensui KUSAKAKijima→Matabe KIJIMATenryu-jiハイフン入れるFukuhara→Echigo FUKUHARAスペル

sen.j: 朝廷内部では長州勢の駆逐を求める強硬派と宥和派が対立し、禁裏御守衛総督を勤める一橋慶喜（徳川慶喜）は退兵を呼びかけるが、京都蛤御門（京都市上京区）付近で長州藩兵が、会津・桑名藩・薩摩各藩の諸隊と衝突、尊皇攘夷を唱える長州勢は壊滅、来島又兵衛、久坂玄瑞、寺島忠三郎らは戦死した。
sen.e: Within the Imperial Court, there was a struggle between hard-liners that wanted to destroy Choshu's military force and others who wished to appease them, while Keiki HITOTSUBASHI (later known as Shogun Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA), who served as Viceroy and Protector of the Imperial Palace, called on the soldiers to withdraw, but the Choshu soldiers clashed with various groups of soldiers from Aizu, Kuwana, and Satsuma domains near Kyoto's Hamaguri Gate (in the Kamikyo ward of modern-day Kyoto); but the forces of Choshu, chanting their Revere the Emperor slogan, were annihilated, and Kijima, Kusaka, and Chusaburo TERAJIMA were among those who died in battle.
sen.cmt: I think it's best to use all capital letters for the family name only the first time the name appears, as it is very unusual to have all capital letters too often in a sentence.
sen.e: Within the Imperial Court, there was a struggle between hard-liners that wanted to destroy Choshu's military force and others who wished to appease them, while Keiki HITOTSUBASHI (later known as Shogun Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA), who served as Viceroy and Protector of the Imperial Palace, called on the soldiers to withdraw, but the Choshu soldiers clashed with various groups of samurai warriors from Aizu, Kuwana, and Satsuma domains near Kyoto's Hamaguri Gate (in the Kamikyo ward of modern-day Kyoto); but the forces of Choshu, chanting their Revere the Emperor slogan, were annihilated, and Kijima, Kusaka, and Chusaburo TERAJIMA were among those who died in battle.

Within the Imperial Court, there was a struggle between hard-liners that wanted to destroy Choshu's military force and others who wished to appease them, while Keiki HITOTSUBASHI (later known as Shogun Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA), who served as Viceroy and Protector of the Imperial Palace, called on the soldiers to withdraw, but the Choshu soldiers clashed with various groups of samurai warriors from Aizu, Kuwana, and Satsuma clans near Kyoto's Hamaguri Gate (in the Kamigyo ward of modern-day Kyoto); but the forces of Choshu, chanting their Revere the Emperor slogan, were annihilated, and Matabe KIJIMA, Gensui KUSAKA, and Chusaburo TERAJIMA were among those who died in battle.

sen.j: 当時、京都守護職であった会津藩主・松平容保は薩摩藩と連携して、長州の尊攘急進派を弾圧する体制を整えていたのである。
sen.e: At that time, the daimyo of Aizu, Katamori MATSUDAIRA, who was charged with the defense of Kyoto, had started cooperating with Satsuma domain, and set up a system to oppress the radical loyalist faction in Choshu.

At that time, the daimyo of Aizu, Katamori MATSUDAIRA, who was charged with the defense of Kyoto, had started cooperating with the Satsuma domain, and set up a system to oppress the radical loyalist faction in Choshu.

At that time, the daimyo of Aizu, Katamori MATSUDAIRA, who was charged with the defense of Kyoto, had started cooperating with the Satsuma clan, and set up a system to oppress the radical loyalist faction in Choshu.

sen.j: 禁門の変に於いて長州藩兵が御所へ向けて発砲した事等を理由に幕府は長州藩を朝敵として、第一次長州征伐を行う。
sen.e: Using the fact that the Choshu loyalists dared to fire their guns in the direction of the Imperial palace during the Hamaguri rebellion as a pretext, the Tokugawa shogunate labeled Choshu domain an official enemy of the Court, and as such launched the First Punitive Expedition against them.

Using the fact that the Choshu loyalists dared to fire their guns in the direction of the Imperial palace during the Hamaguri rebellion as a pretext, the Tokugawa shogunate labeled Choshu domain an official enemy of the Court, and as such launched the First Punitive Expedition against them.

Using the fact that the Choshu loyalists dared to fire their guns in the direction of the Imperial palace during the Hamaguri rebellion as a pretext, the Tokugawa shogunate labeled Choshu domain an official enemy of the Court, and as such launched the First Punitive Expedition against them.

sen.j: 戦闘の後、落ち延びる長州勢は長州藩屋敷に火を放ち逃走、会津勢も長州藩士の隠れているとされた中立売御門付近の家屋を攻撃した。
sen.e: After the battle, those of the Choshu forces who managed to escape set fire to the Choshu estate in Kyoto and fled, while the Aizu forces attacked an estate near the Nakadachiuri Gate, which was thought to be where Choshu soldiers were hiding.

After the battle, the Choshu forces, who managed to escape, set fire to the Choshu estate in Kyoto and fled, while the Aizu forces attacked an estate near the Nakadachiuri Gate, thought to be where Choshu soldiers were hiding.
sen.cmt: deleted "those of" before "Choshu forces" commas added after "forces" and after "escape," deleted "which was" before "thought to be"
sen.e: After the battle, the Choshu forces, who managed to escape, set fire to the Choshu estate in Kyoto and fled, while the Aizu forces attacked an estate near the Nakadachiuri Gate, thought to be where Choshu soldiers were hiding.

sen.j: この二箇所から上がった火で京都市街は「どんどん焼け」と呼ばれる大火に見舞われ、北は一条通から南は七条の真宗本廟に至る広い範囲の街区や社寺が焼失した。
sen.e: Because of the flames rising from these two places the neighborhoods and entire city of Kyoto were struck by the great fire known as the "don-don yake" (quick quick burning), in which everything between Ichijo avenue on the north all the way to the Main Mausoleum of the Shin (Pure Land) Sect (which refers to Higashi Honganji temple) on Shichijo avenue to the south, a wide swath of land and many temples and shrines, were destroyed by fire.

Because of the flames rising from these two places the neighborhoods and the entire city of Kyoto were struck by the great fire known as the "don-don yake" (quick quick burning), in which everything between Ichijo avenue on the north all the way to the Main Mausoleum of the Shin (Pure Land) Sect (which refers to Higashi Honganji temple) on Shichijo avenue to the south, a wide swath of land and many temples and shrines, were destroyed by fire.

Because of the flames rising from these two places the neighborhoods and the entire city of Kyoto were struck by the great fire known as the 'don-don yake' (quick quick burning), in which everything between Ichijo avenue on the north all the way to the Main Mausoleum of the Shin (Pure Land) Sect (which refers to Higashi Hongan-ji temple) on Shichijo avenue to the south, a wide swath of land and many temples and shrines, were destroyed by fire.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'にHongan-jiハイフン挿入
